awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2024 19th Annual Graduate Students Combinatorics Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The 19th Annual Graduate Student Combinatorics Conference (GSCC) will be held from March 15-17, 2024, at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, PA. The GSCC is organized by and for graduate students, and includes many subfields of combinatorics, including algebraic, topological, additive, and probabilistic combinatorics. The goal of GSCC is to provide a welcoming environment for graduate students to present their research, learn about the research of others, and meet and collaborate with other students in their field. Carnegie Mellon is well-known for its strength in combinatorics and the applications of combinatorics to computer science. Through a conference for graduate students, the hope is to provide support and encouragement to the next generation of researchers in this thriving subject, as such the aim is to make it accessible and inclusive to a broad spectrum of students. 

The main feature of the GSCC is that graduate student attendees are invited to present 25-minute talks on their research, which will run in parallel sessions. There will be four plenary speakers, who are all distinguished professors within different subfields of combinatorics: Jane Pu Gao (Waterloo), Thomas Lam (Michigan), Igor Pak (UCLA), and Michael Young (Carnegie Mellon). Conference registration (free) will open by January, as will applications for travel support. More information for the GSCC is available at sites.google.com/view/GSCC2024.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Combinatorics is a popular and ever-growing subfield within modern mathematics, and is one of the most applicable fields to modern computing and optimization. Carnegie Mellon University is known for its strong programs in combinatorics and computer science. The plan was to strengthen the combinatorics community in the United States by providing a venue for the next generation of combinatorics researchers to collaborate, network, and give presentations.

Besides showcasing the inspiring research of four stellar faculty as the keynote speakers, the conference featured 56 student speakers, and hosted a total of 120 partcipants from colleges and universities across the nation. The topics covered all aspects of combinatorics including algebraic, extremal, geometric, and probabilistic combinatorics.

The keynote speakers were Jane Gao (University of Waterloo, Canada), Thomas Lam (University of Michigan), Igor Pak (UCLA), and Michael Young (CMU).Graduate students presented their work to their peers and gained experience and exposure to different subfields within combinatorics. The conference encouraged more participation and research within combinatorics, which will very likely lead to new developments in related applied fields such as computing.

The primary goal of the GSCC was to create a stronger community within combinatorics, and thus to grow the field. Research is often most productive when researchers have the opportunity to work with others. The conference promoted accessibility and inclusivity within combinatorics, by welcoming graduate students from all backgrounds.

More information regarding the schedule of talks, abstracts of the lectures delivered, and other details are all available publicly at the following website:

https://sites.google.com/view/gscc2024


Last Modified: 03/24/2025
Modified by: Prasad Tetali
